The source categories for the delegation of authority include hot mix asphalt facilities, petroleum refineries, storage vessels for petroleum liquids, bulk gasoline terminals, equipment leaks of VOC from onshore natural gas processing plants, and VOC emissions from petroleum refinery wastewater systems. This notice is effective on 10/25/2007.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Outer Continental Shelf air regulations; Consistency update for California
Abstract: EPA is finalizing the updates of the Outer Continental Shelf (OCS) Air Regulations proposed in the Federal Register on 3/23/2006, 8/18/2006, and 5/31/2007. Requirements applying to OCS sources located within 25 mi of states' seaward boundaries must be updated periodically to remain consistent with the requirements of the corresponding onshore area, as mandated by section 328(a)(1) of the CAAA. The portions of the OCS air regulations that are being updated pertain to the requirements for OCS sources for which the Ventura County Air Pollution Control District is the designated COA. The intended effect of approving the requirements contained in "Ventura County Air Pollution Control District Requirements Applicable to OCS Sources" (September 2007) is to regulate emissions from OCS sources in accordance with the requirements onshore. This rule is effective on 11/23/2007. The subjects listed in 40 CFR Part 55 include environmental protection, administrative practice and procedures, air pollution control, hydrocarbons, incorporation by reference, intergovernmental relations, NO2, NOx, O3, particulate matter, permits, reporting and recordkeeping requirements, and SOx.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Government & policy concentrates: Two programs to fight climate change
Abstract: The World Bank will begin two programs to help developing countries protect their forests and reduce CO2 emissions from other sources. One program will compensate developing countries for CO2 reduction achieved by maintaining their forests. The other program, the Carbon partnership Facility, will improve energy efficiency, reduce natural-gas flaring, and foster urban development that minimizes greenhouse gas emissions. Both programs will show ways to ratchet up the fight against climate change by adopting a larger scale, longer term approach to greenhouse gas emission reductions.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Drilling & production - Quick takes: Colorado gas plant catches CO2 for EOR
Abstract: Blue Source LLC announced the startup of a CO2 reduction, carbon offset project at the AppleTree LLC gas processing plant in Huerfano County, CO. The CO2 is being sold for use in EOR in the Permian basin. Gas produced from Oakdale field is 22% methane and 78% CO2. The carbon capture and storage project is reducing CO2 emissions by about 44,000 ton/yr.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval of implementation plans of Illinois: Clean air interstate rule
Abstract: EPA is approving a revision to the Illinois SIP submitted on 9/14/2007, which addresses the requirements of EPA's Clean Air Interstate Rule (CAIR), promulgated on 5/12/2005, and subsequently revised on 4/28/2006, and 12/13/2006. EPA will also withdraw the CAIR Federal Implementation Plans (CAIR FIP) concerning SO2, NOx annual, and NOx ozone season emissions for Illinois. CAIR requires States to reduce emissions of SO2 and NOx that significantly contribute to, and interfere with maintenance of, the NAAQS for fine particulates and ozone in any downwind state. In the SIP revision that EPA is approving, Illinois meets CAIR requirements by participating in the EPA-administered cap-and-trade programs addressing SO2, NOx annual, and NOx ozone season emissions. This direct final rule will be effective 12/17/2007, unless EPA receives adverse comments by 11/15/2007. If adverse comments are received, EPA will publish a timely withdrawal of the direct final rule in the Federal Register informing the public that the rule will not take effect.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Processing - Quick takes: Hunt Refining settles air pollution charges
Abstract: The US Department of Justice and EPA jointly announced on 9/28/2007 that Hunt Refining Co and Hunt Southland Refining Co agreed to pay a $400,000 fine and spend > $548.5 million for new and upgraded pollution controls at three refineries. The settlement resolves alleged violations of the federal Clean Air Act and is expected to reduce by > 1250 ton/yr the harmful emissions from the company's refineries in Tuscaloosa, AL, and Sandersville and Lumberton, MS. The plants have a combined throughput capacity of nearly 70,000 bpd. New pollution controls to be installed under the agreement will reduce annual NOx emissions at the refineries by 150 ton and SO2 by almost 1100 ton when fully implemented. The controls also will reduce the plants' VOC and particulate matter emissions. Hunt also agreed to spend $475,000 on projects to benefit the environment. The company has agreed to upgrade controls to reduce VOC emissions from the Tuscaloosa refinery's wastewater emissions and to buy emergency preparedness equipment and train mutual aid responders in Vicksburg, MS, and Choctaw County, AL. Alabama and Mississippi joined in the settlement and will share equal portions of the fine with EPA.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plans; Florida; Clean air interstate rule
Abstract: EPA is taking final action to approve a revision to the Florida SIP submitted on 3/16/2007, which addresses the requirements of EPA's Clean Air Interstate Rule (CAIR) promulgated on 5/12/2005, and subsequently revised on 4/28/2006, and 12/13/2006. EPA has determined that the SIP revision fully implements the CAIR requirements for Florida. Thus, EPA will also withdraw, through a separate rulemaking, the CAIR Federal Implementation Plans (FIP) concerning SO2, NOx annual, and NOx ozone season emissions for Florida. The CAIR FIP for all States in the CAIR region were promulgated on 4/28/2006, and subsequently revised on 12/13/2006. CAIR requires States to reduce emissions of SO2 and NOx that significantly contribute to, and interfere with maintenance of, the NAAQS for fine particulates (PM2.5) and/or ozone in any downwind state. CAIR establishes State budgets for SO2 and NOx and requires States to submit SIP revisions that implement these budgets in States that EPA concluded did contribute to nonattainment in downwind states. In the SIP revision that EPA is approving, Florida has met the CAIR requirements by electing to participate in the EPA-administered cap-and-trade programs addressing SO2, NOx annual, and NOx ozone season emissions. This rule is effective on 11/13/2007.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; State of South Dakota; Revisions to the administrative rules of South Dakota
Abstract: EPA is taking direct final action approving a SIP revisions submitted by the State of South Dakota on 8/8/2006. The 8/8/2006 submittal revises the Administrative Rules of South Dakota, Air Pollution Control Program, by modifying the chapters pertaining to definitions, ambient air quality, air quality episodes, operating permits for minor sources, performance testing, control of visible emissions, and continuous emission monitoring systems. The intended effect of this action is to make these revisions federally enforceable. EPA is also announcing that on 7/19/2007, it updated the delegation of authority for the implementation and enforcement of the New Source Performance Standards to the State of South Dakota. These actions are being taken under sections 110 and 111 of the Clean Air Act. This rule is effective on 12/10/2007 without further notice, unless EPA receives adverse comment by 11/13/2007. List of subjects in 40 CFR Part 52 includes environmental protection, CO, NO2, ozone, particulate matter, SOx, VOC.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; Pennsylvania; Carbon monoxide maintenance plan update; limited maintenance plan in Philadelphia county
Abstract: EPA is taking direct final action to approve a revision to the Pennsylvania SIP that was submitted on 3/19/2007 by the Pennsylvania Department of the Environment. This revision is a conversion of the currently approved full maintenance plan for CO for the years 2007-2017, to a maintenance plan that will use a limited maintenance plan option for the same period. This will allow Federal actions requiring conformity determinations to be considered as automatically satisfying the budget test for CO. EPA is approving these revisions to the Philadelphia County CO maintenance plan in accordance with the requirements of the Clean Air Act. This action is being taken under section 110 of the Act. This rule is effective on 12/4/2007, without further notice, unless EPA receives adverse written comment by 11/5/2007. If EPA receives such comments, it will publish a timely withdrawal of the direct final rule in the Federal Register and inform the public that the rule will not take effect.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval of implementation plans of Kentucky: Clean air interstate rule
Abstract: EPA is approving a revision to the Kentucky SIP submitted on 7/19/2007. This revision addresses the requirements of EPA's Clean Air Interstate Rule (CAIR), promulgated on 5/12/2005, and subsequently revised on 4/28/2006, and 12/13/2006. EPA has determined that the SIP revision fully implements the CAIR requirements for Kentucky. Therefore, as a consequence of the SIP approval, EPA will also withdraw the CAIR Federal Implementation Plans (FIP) concerning SO2, NOx annual, and NOx ozone season emissions for Kentucky. The CAIR FIP for all States in the CAIR region were promulgated on 4/28/2006, and subsequently revised on 12/13/2006. CAIR requires States to reduce emissions of SO2 and NOx that significantly contribute to, and interfere with maintenance of, the NAAQS for fine particulates and/or ozone in any downwind state. CAIR establishes State budgets for SO2 and NOx and requires States to submit SIP revisions that implement these budgets in States that EPA concluded did contribute to nonattainment in downwind states. In the SIP revision that EPA is approving, Kentucky would meet CAIR requirements by participating in the EPA-administered cap-and-trade programs addressing SO2, NOx annual, and NOx ozone season emissions. This direct final rule is effective on 12/3/2007, without further notice, unless EPA receives adverse comment by 11/5/2007. If EPA receives such comments, it will publish a timely withdrawal of the direct final rule in the Federal Register and inform the public that the rule will not take effect.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plans; Mississippi: Clean air interstate rule
Abstract: EPA is taking final action to approve a revision to the Mississippi SIP submitted on 1/16/2007. This revision addresses the requirements of EPA's Clean Air Interstate Rule (CAIR) promulgated on 5/12/2005, and subsequently revised on 4/28/2006, and 12/13/2006. EPA has determined that the SIP revision fully implements the CAIR requirements for Mississippi. As a result of this action, EPA will also withdraw, through a separate rulemaking, the CAIR Federal Implementation Plans (FIP) concerning SO2, NOx annual, and NOx ozone season emissions for Mississippi. The CAIR FIP for all States in the CAIR region were promulgated on 4/28/2006, and subsequently revised on 12/13/2006. CAIR requires States to reduce emissions of SO2 and NOx that significantly contribute to, and interfere with maintenance of, the NAAQS for fine particulates (PM2.5) and/or ozone in any downwind state. CAIR establishes State budgets for SO2 and NOx and requires States to submit SIP revisions that implement these budgets in States that EPA concluded did contribute to non-attainment in downwind states. States have the flexibility to choose which control measures to adopt to achieve the budgets, including participating in the EPA-administered cap-and-trade programs. In the SIP revision that EPA is approving today, Mississippi has met the CAIR requirements by electing to participate in the EPA-administered cap-and-trade programs addressing SO2, NOx annual, and NOx ozone season emissions for Mississippi. This rule is effective on 11/2/2007.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Depths of Lake Ontario offer energy efficiency
Abstract: The Deep Lake Water Cooling (DLWC) system in Toronto is the world's largest cooling system providing natural air conditioning. DLWC is operated by Enwave energy, a private corporation co-owned by city of Toronto and the Ontario Municipal Employees Retirement System (OMERS). A single source of water provides cooling for Enwave's DLWC system and drinking water for the city. DWLC consumes only a tenth the electricity compared to conventional chillers. DLWC systems reduces greenhouse gases and eliminates large quantities of ozone-depleting refrigerants. Enwave has turned to SRB controls Inc., of Markham, Ontario, which recommended the IFS 4000 KC Enviromag electromagnetic flowmeter (EMF). The EMF requires absolutely no maintenance and there are no mechanically moving parts. An electrically conductive fluid flows through an obstructed insulating tube and through a constant magnetic field.
Index Keywords: Energy efficiency; Maintenance; Potable water; Refrigerants; Conductive fluid flows; Conventional chillers; Cooling systems

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: The cable guys
Abstract: Cabling systems specialist Nexans has introduced an innovative hybrid MV (medium-voltage) ship-to-shore connection cable that helps ships berthed in port to cut their engines and plug in to the local power grid and providing an integral data and telecommunication link. This cable will help large ships to make use of AMP (alternative maritime power) systems that effectively eliminate the production of greenhouse gases while in port, and reducing noise emissions and saving on fuel costs. The advanced cabling solution is aimed mainly at the advanced generation of large container vessels, LNG tankers, ferries, and cruiseships, which require vast quantities of electric power to support heating, air conditioning, lighting, and computer control systems. The cable also integrates MV power supply, and controls cores and optical fibers for data transmission such as telephone and Internet in a single, rugged cable, designed to be easy to reel either from onboard or from portside.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Acrimony marks international emissions-control discussions
Abstract: The European Union (EU) and international aviation organizations are taking different initiatives to reduce greenhouse gas emission. The Air Transport Association of America has objected the litigations over Europe's perceived unilateral approach. The international Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) has adopted a plan at its triennial assembly, but has rejected European Commission (EC) proposals calling for high-level officials to include airlines in emission trading scheme (ETS). The total industry emissions have increased, despite some improvements in aircraft emission, as more flights took off as a result of the emergence of cheap air travel. The European States have indicated their intention to unilaterally impose emission trading scheme for the aviation industry.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Moulding the future of the planet
Abstract: European Community has taken a major step, which would help plastic processors to maximize their energy efficiency and to combat the problems associated with global warming. The step taken is a project, RECIPE (Reduced Energy Consumption in Plastics Engineering), which will provide the plastic processors with the knowledge, justification, and tools, needed to reduced energy consumption, which in turn will reduce the carbon dioxide emission, a major factor in triggering the global warming. The project delivers a practice guide for plastic processors, an interactive tool kit for evaluation of energy consumption, and a cost of ownership model (COM).The COM, a software of RECIPE, is used to evaluate the cost of an injection molded part, and also provide lifetime cost of the part and costs for different elements. The best feature of COM is its ability to make comparisons between different machine for the same part, either with the same mold or with a mold using different cavitation.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Interconnect: Future nodes look beyond copper
Abstract: Although copper interconnects have become essential to the continuation of Moore's Law, they too have limits. Scattering effects lead to exponential increases in resistance as linewidth falls. Design optimizations and enhanced barrier layers can help minimize these effects. Still, 22nm generation devices may force process engineers to consider such radical new interconnect schemes as carbon nanotubes.
Index Keywords: Carbon nanotubes; Copper; Electromagnetic wave scattering; Optimization; Process engineering; Barrier layers; Copper interconnects; Moore's Law; Solid state device structures

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Frankfurt's economy drive
Abstract: The carmakers in the Frankfurt car show emphasized economy and emission reduction as a priority both for current vehicles and future concepts. VW's 'Up' concept in the show was a 3.45 rear-engined city car seating that can be altered to allow almost the whole interior to accommodate luggage. Ford used a reduction in resistance, both in aerodynamics and from a new transmission oil developed by BP for its economic improvements. OEM is preparing its E-Flex architecture for volume production, which extend the battery's range by using the Corsa's 1.3-liter diesel, enhanced with piezo in-cylinder pressure. The C-Cactus demonstrated some of the weight and cost-saving measures PSA has been examining to make diesel hybrids useful. OEM also plans for massive development of cost-optimized stop/start systems. Renault also displayed a concept version of a Diesel V6 it is developing with Nissan that produces a very substantial 195kW/550 Nm.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: State rules: Texas - VOCs targeted by HAWK
Abstract: A study was conducted by the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality to identify sources of VOC emissions. The results will be used to develop plans to reduce emissions from these sources. A specialized IR camera, called the HAWK, can image VOC emissions that are invisible to the eye. Helicopters equipped with the device have been flying over pipelines, oil and gas production, and other industrial areas in Collin, Dallas, Denton, Ellis, Johnson, Kaufman, Parker, Rockwall, Tarrant, Wise, and Hood counties.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: State rules: Kansas - KC ozone plan gets green light
Abstract: Kansas' plan to reduce ground-level ozone in the Kansas City area got the green light from the federal EPA. Steps the state will take include drafting regulations to limit power plant emissions and idling commercial diesel vehicles in the Kansas City metro area. Other measures include voluntary programs to reduce emissions and local plans to educate residents about things they can do to curb air pollution.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plans; New York; Clean Air Interstate Rule
Abstract: EPA is proposing to approve a revision to the New York SIP that addresses the requirements of EPA's Clean Air Interstate Rule (CAIR), promulgated on 5/12/2005 and subsequently revised on 4/28/2006, and 12/13/2006. The agency is proposing to determine that the SIP revision fully implements the CAIR requirements for New York. EPA will also withdraw the CAIR Federal Implementation Plans concerning SO2, NOx annual, and NOx ozone season emissions for New York pending final approval of New York's SIP revision. CAIR requires states to reduce emissions of SO2 and NOx that significantly contribute to and interfere with the maintenance of the NAAQS for fine particulates and/or ozone in any downwind state. CAIR establishes state budgets for SO2 and NOx and requires states, which EPA has concluded contribute to nonattainment in downwind states, to submit SIP revisions that implement these budgets. In the SIP revision that EPA is proposing to approve, New York would meet CAIR requirements by participating in the EPA-administered cap-and-trade programs addressing SO2, NOx annual, and NOx ozone season emissions. Comments must be received on or before 10/31/2007.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; Indiana; oxides of nitrogen regulations, phase II
Abstract: EPA is approving the Phase II Rule, submitted by Indiana on 3/8/2006 and supplemented on 6/22/2006, to control NOx emissions from IC engines in Indiana. EPA is approving these regulations based on Indiana's demonstration that they will result in the achievement of the Phase II budget through source compliance with rules affecting stationary internal combustion (IC) engines which are identified in the NOx plan submittal. Limiting NOx emissions from IC engines will enable the State to meet the Phase II incremental difference of 4244 ton during the ozone season, thereby improving air quality and protecting the health of Indiana citizens. EPA is also approving other changes to Indiana's NOx rules, i.e., minor clerical corrections and changes in definitions made by Indiana to conform to the revisions made by EPA in the Phase II Rule. This final rule is effective on 10/31/2007.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plans; Louisiana; clean air interstate rule nitrogen oxides trading programs
Abstract: EPA is approving a revision to the Louisiana SIP submitted by the State of Louisiana on 8/20/2007, as the Louisiana CAIR NOx Trading Programs abbreviated SIP. The abbreviated SIP revision includes the Louisiana methodology for allocation of annual and ozone season NOx allowances. EPA has determined that the Louisiana CAIR NOx Trading Programs abbreviated SIP revision satisfies the applicable requirements of a CAIR abbreviated SIP revision. EPA is also approving revisions to the Louisiana SIP that establish administrative reporting requirements for all Louisiana CAIR programs; these revisions were submitted on 9/22/2006, as part of the Louisiana CAIR SO2 Trading Program SIP. EPA has also determined that the Louisiana CAIR NOx Annual and Ozone Season Abbreviated SIP satisfies Louisiana's Clean Air Act (CAA) Section 110(a)(2)(D)(i) obligations to submit a SIP revision that contains adequate provisions to prohibit air emissions from adversely affecting another State's air quality through interstate transport. The intended effect of this action is to reduce NOx emissions from the State of Louisiana that are contributing to nonattainment of the 8-hour ozone and PM2.6 NAAQS in downwind states. This action is being taken under section 110 of the CAA. This rule is effective on 9/28/2007.

Authors: Committee to Review the U.S. Climate Change Science Program's Synthesis and Assessment Product 3.2, Board on Atmospheric Sciences and Climate, Division on Earth and Life Studies, National Research Council
Title: Review of the U.S. Climate Change Science Program's Synthesis and Assessment Product 3.2, "Climate Projections Based on Emission Scenarios for Long-lived and Short-lived Radiatively Active Gases and Aerosols"
Source title: Review of the U.S. Climate Change Science Program's Synthesis and Assessment Product 3.2, "Climate Projections Based on Emission Scenarios for Long-lived and Short-lived Radiatively Active Gases and Aerosols"
Authors with affiliations: Committee to Review the U.S. Climate Change Science Program's Synthesis and Assessment Product 3.2; Board on Atmospheric Sciences and Climate; Division on Earth and Life Studies; National Research Council
Abstract: This report has been reviewed in draft form by individuals chosen for their diverse perspectives and technical expertise, in accordance with procedures approved by the National Research Council's Report Review Committee. The purpose of this independent review is to provide candid and critical comments that will assist the institution in making its published report as sound as possible and to ensure that the report meets institutional standards for objectivity, evidence, and responsiveness to the study charge. The review comments and draft manuscript remain confidential to protect the integrity of the deliberative process. We wish to thank the following individuals for their review of this report. © 2007 National Academy of Sciences. All rights reserved.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; Ohio
Abstract: EPA is approving a request from Ohio to amend its SIP emission statement reporting regulation. The request to revise Ohio's SIP was submitted by the Division of Air Pollution Control on 5/1/2006, and supplemented on 5/22/2007. Ohio held a public hearing on these revisions on 9/8/2005. The SIP revision concurrently rescinds and revises portions of Ohio Administrative Code Chapter 3745-24 to be consistent with the Clean Air Act emission statement program reporting requirements for stationary sources. The revision makes the rule more general to apply to all counties designated nonattainment for ozone, and not to a specific list of counties. This direct final rule will be effective on 11/26/2007, unless EPA receives adverse comments by 10/29/2007. If adverse comments are received, EPA will publish a timely withdrawal of the direct final rule in the Federal Register informing the public that the rule will not take effect. List of subjects in 40 CFR Part 52 include environmental protection, air pollution control, incorporation by reference, NO2, ozone, reporting and recordkeeping requirements, and VOC.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plans; Arkansas; Clean air interstate rule nitrogen oxides ozone season trading program
Abstract: EPA is approving a revision to the Arkansas SIP submitted on 8/10/2007, enacted at Regulation 19-Arkansas Plan of Implementation for Air Pollution Control; Chapter 14, Sections 19.1401-19.1404; and Chapter 15, Section 19.1501. This revision addresses the requirements of EPA's Clean Air Interstate Rule (CAIR) NOx Ozone Season Trading Program. In this direct final rule, EPA is approving the SIP revision as fully implementing the CAIR NOX ozone season requirements for Arkansas. As a consequence, EPA will also withdraw the CAIR Federal Implementation Plan (CAIR FIP) concerning NOx ozone season emissions for Arkansas. This action aims to reduce NOx emissions from the State of Arkansas that are contributing to nonattainment of the 8-hr ozone NAAQS in downwind states. This rule is effective on 11/26/2007 without further notice, unless EPA receives relevant adverse comment by 10/26/2007.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; Virginia; Clean air interstate rule budget trading programs
Abstract: EPA is proposing to approve a revision to the Virginia SIP submitted on 3/30/2007 and supplemented on 4/30/2007 and 6/11/2007. EPA is proposing to determine that the SIP revision fully implements the CAIR requirements for Virginia. Therefore, as a consequence of the SIP approval, EPA will also withdraw the CAIR Federal Implementation Plans (FIP) that address SO2, NOx annual, and NOx ozone season emissions in Virginia. The CAIR requires affected States to reduce emissions of SO2 and NOx that significantly contribute to, and interfere with maintenance of, the NAAQS for fine particulates and/or ozone in any downwind state. In the SIP revision that EPA is proposing to approve, Virginia would meet CAIR requirements by participating in the EPA-administered cap-and-trade programs addressing SO2, NOx annual, and NOx ozone season emissions. Written comments must be received on or before 10/25/2007.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Prevention of significant deterioration (PSD) for particulate matter less than 2.5 micrometers (PM2.5)-increments, significant impact levels (SILs) and significant monitoring concentration (SMC)
Abstract: The Clean Air Act authorizes EPA to establish regulations to prevent significant deterioration of air quality due to emissions of any pollutant for which a NAAQS has been promulgated. The NAAQS for particulate matter using the PM2.5 indicator were promulgated in 1997. The EPA is proposing to facilitate implementation of a PM2.5 PSD program in areas attaining the PM2.5 NAAQS by developing PM2.5 increments, SIL, and a SMC. Comments must be received on or before 11/20/2007. Entities potentially affected by this proposed action include owners and operators of emission sources in all industry groups (e.g., petroleum refining, NGL, natural gas transport), as well as the EPA and state, local, and tribal governments that are delegated authority to implement these regulations.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Government & policy concentrates: Court says states may regulate greenhouse gases
Abstract: A federal trial court ruled that states may regulate greenhouse gas emissions from new cars and trucks. Rejecting automakers' arguments, the US District Court in Vermont stated that state controls on greenhouse gas emissions do not conflict with federal fuel economy standards. The case builds on the US Supreme Court's decision in April 2007 that vehicle emissions of CO2 can be controlled under the federal Clean Air Act. The governors of 13 states asked the heads of car firms to withdraw legal challenges to state regulation of greenhouse gas emissions from vehicles.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plans; Missouri; Clean air interstate rule
Abstract: EPA is proposing to approve a revision to the Missouri SIP submitted on 5/18/2007. This revision addresses the requirements of EPA's Clean Air Interstate Rule (CAIR), promulgated on 5/12/2005, and subsequently revised on 4/28/2006, and 12/13/2006. EPA is proposing to determine that the SIP revision fully meets the CAIR requirements for Missouri. If EPA approves the revisions, it will also withdraw the CAIR Federal Implementation Plans (CAIR FIP) concerning SO2, NOx annual, NOx ozone season emissions for Missouri. The CAIR FIP for all States in the CAIR region were promulgated on 4/28/2006, and subsequently revised on 12/13/2006. CAIR requires States to reduce emissions of SO2 and NOx that significantly contribute to, and interfere with maintenance of, the NAAQS for fine particulates and/or ozone in any downwind state. CAIR establishes State budgets for SO2 and NOx and requires States to submit SIP revisions that implement these budgets in States that EPA concluded did contribute to nonattainment in downwind states. States have the flexibility to choose which control measures to adopt to achieve the budgets, including participating in the EPA-administered cap-and-trade programs. In the SIP revision that EPA is proposing to approve, Missouri would meet CAIR requirements by participating in the EPA-administered cap-and-trade programs addressing SO2, NOx annual, and NOx ozone season emissions. Comments must be received on or before 10/17/2007.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Revisions to the California state implementation plan, Mojave desert air quality management district
Abstract: EPA is taking direct final action to approve a revision to the Mojave Desert Air Quality Management District (MDAQMD) portion of the California SIP. VOC help produce ground-level ozone and smog, which harm human health and the environment. Section 110(a) of the CAAA requires states to submit regulations that control VOC emissions. This rule was developed as part of the local air district's programs to control these pollutants. This revision concerns VOC emissions from the usage of solvents. The agency is approving a local rule that regulates these emission sources under the CAAA. This rule is effective on 11/16/2007 without further notice, unless EPA receives adverse comments by 10/17/2007. List of Subjects in 40 CFR Part 52 include environmental protection, air pollution control, incorporation by reference, intergovernmental relations, ozone, reporting and recordkeeping requirements, and VOC.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; Indiana; VOC emissions from fuel grade ethanol production operations
Abstract: EPA is approving a 3/30/2007 request from the Indiana Department of Environmental Management to revise the Indiana SIP by adding a VOC rule for fuel grade ethanol production at dry mills. This rule revision creates an industry-specific BACT standard for new fuel grade ethanol production dry mills that replaces the otherwise required case-by-case SIP BACT determination for new facilities with the potential to emit ≥ 25 ton/yr of VOC. The benefit of this rule is that establishing specific standards in place of a case-by-case analysis improves the clarity, predictability, and timeliness of certain State permit decisions. This direct final rule will be effective on 11/13/2007, unless EPA receives adverse comments by 10/15/2007.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; Ohio; Oxides of nitrogen budget trading program
Abstract: EPA is proposing to approve Ohio's request to permanently retire 240 NOx allowances from the State's 2005 new source set aside, which would otherwise have been distributed to existing sources that are required participants in the State of Ohio's NOx budget. Under the Federal NOx Budget Trading Program, each participating state receives a main pool of "allowances", which are credits that permit a source to emit 1 ton/allowance of NOx. Allowances are apportioned state-wide to electricity generating units and other large NOx sources which are subject to the budget trading program. Retiring 240 new source set aside allowances will provide surplus emission reductions to help compensate for the discontinuation of Ohio's "E-Check" motor vehicle inspection and maintenance program in the Cincinnati and Dayton areas for the year 2006. Withholding and permanently retiring 240 new source set aside allowances from the year 2006 control period will provide 240 ton of surplus NOx emission reductions that are creditable for replacing reductions that otherwise would have occurred from the E-Check program during the 2006 ozone season. Comments must be received on or before 10/15/2007.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Government & policy concentrates: California has strong case on CO2
Abstract: According to the Congressional Research Service (CRS), California has made "a strong case" for getting permission from EPA to regulate greenhouse gas emissions from new cars. California has been waiting since December 2005 for EPA to decide whether to give the state the authority to limit greenhouse gas emissions from new vehicles. If EPA grants the request, 11 more states are poised to follow California's lead. In an analysis completed in late August 2007, CRS determined that California has solid legal arguments for earning EPA's approval under the Clean Air Act for the new-vehicle emission standards. However, it did not study provisions of a law that EPA does not administer the 1975 Energy Policy & Conservation Act that could preclude California from implementing the greenhouse gas regulation. Automakers argue that the state's plan is simply a method for regulating vehicles' fuel economy, which, under the 1975 laws is a job reserved solely for the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Government & policy concentrates: Pollution controls on refineries deemed sufficient
Abstract: After the study conducted on the risks from toxic air emissions from refineries that have installed pollution control equipment as required by federal regulation, API has declared the effectiveness of the emission controls the refinery industry has implemented. However, according to the Natural Resources Defense Council, EPA found what NRDC calls a significant cancer risk - 70 cases/1 million people - from the air toxics now emitted by refineries and therefore needs to impose further controls. In light of its own conclusions, EPA is considering two future regulatory options for emissions of air toxics at refineries. One would require no additional emission cuts. The other would involve reductions in hazardous air pollutant releases from storage vessels and wastewater treatment units at refineries.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Airbag technology
Abstract: Carbon capture and storage process permanently isolates CO2 from the atmosphere in underground geological formations, which is also called an "airbag technology", according to George Peridas, a climate scientist at the Natural Resources Defense Council. According to the UN Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, the world's most authoritative body studying climate change, emissions must peak in the next 10-20 yr to limit global temperature increases to 2-2.4°C above pre-industrial levels - generally regarded as the threshold at which the more extreme effects of climate change will begin. Because there is no chance of phasing out fossil fuels in the next two decades, something must be done about the CO2. CO2 emissions should be cut by 50-80% by 2050, according to IPCC. Managing such a large reduction in emissions during such a demand-growth spurt would be a strong phenomenal achievement - especially because the use of coal, the dirtiest fossil fuel, is expected to rise rapidly. The reasons for optimism are discussed.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Legal: EU: Lithuania sues over CO2
Abstract: Lithuania is taking the European Commission to the European Court of Justice over the decision by the EU executive to cut its annual CO2 emissions by 50% to 8.8 million ton for the period 2008-2012. Lithuania has asked for a CO2 allowance of 11.2 million ton/yr. The cuts by the Commission are part of a drive to improve the effectiveness of the carbon-trading scheme, after it was derided for not being strict enough. The over-generous allowances caused the price of carbon credits to collapse, underlining the need for tougher limits second time round. However, Lithuania and the other complainants, including Hungary, the Czech Republic, Slovakia, Latvia and Estonia, claim the Commission has exceeded its authority and used the wrong calculation methods. The cuts have been severe. Poland was allocated 208.5 million ton/yr of emissions for the period 2008-2012 period, down by nearly 27% from the 285 million ton/yr it had sought. And the Czech Republic originally sought a quota of 101.9 million ton/yr, but that was cut to 86.8 million ton/yr. What worries these countries is that the stricter carbon caps will crimp economic growth. Such economic growth needs fuel and this for the foreseeable future will come primarily from coal, which dominates the region's power sectors.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Top of the news: Oil industry seeks reasonable time to meet new fuel rules
Abstract: The Western States Petroleum Association (Sacramento) has petitioned the CARB for a more reasonable timeframe for meeting new fuels rules approved by the board in early summer 2007. The amended California's reformulated gasoline rules to permit increased use of ethanol and lower carbon fuels. The rules give refiners 2 yr to comply or face punitive and costly penalties. The California Energy Commission and refining companies at the CARB hearing demonstrated that fuels projects of this magnitude would require reasonable time frame for companies to complete the complex tasks of designing new refining system, obtaining several permits from different agencies, complying with the California Environmental Quality Act, and constructing the new facilities, testing, and putting them into operation.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Dubai Metro 'Gautrain' in a desert country
Abstract: Several leading international companies have formed a joint consortium, called Dubai Urban Rapid Link (DURL), to design and build metro rail transportation network for the city. One of the main objectives of the project is to implement the Dubai Metro as an alternative mode of transport with three main goals, such as reduce dependence on car transport facility, reduce traveling time in and around the city, and to help reduce traffic-based air pollution. The metro network will also link one end of the city to the CBD and Dubai International Airport on the other end. Provisions will also be made under the metro rail project for developing park and ride facilities near some of the main stations. Interlinked bus, taxi routes, and water bus routes will also be developed, to complement the city's public transportation network.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Tenneco makes clean air acquisition... Eaton hybrid goes commercial... helping truckers find biodiesel
Abstract: Tenneco Inc. has signed an agreement to acquire the mobile emissions business of Combustion Components Associates Inc. (CCA), a manufacturer of air pollution control technologies for the transporatation and power generation industry. The company's system integration capabilities for selective catalyst reduction (SCR) emissions controlled technologies designed to meet future more strict diesel emissions regulations for passenger cars and trucks. Emissions control systems manufacturer CleanAIR Systems has been included in the Clean Diesel Technology/Off-Road Field-Testing Program at the New York city Department of Sanitation (DSNY). The Volvo Group has unveiled seven demonstrations trucks in Stockholm, which are powered by the company's own 9 L engines modified to operate on seven different types of renewable liquids.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: News: Government: Latest developments from the EU
Abstract: The European Commission (EC) and EU member states are squaring up ahead of a political battle over anticipated energy liberalization proposals. A letter from France, Germany, Austria, Bulgaria, Cyprus, Greece, Latvia, Luxembourg, and Slovakia has been written to the EC stating the nations' firm opposition to comprehensive energy unbundling in anticipated proposed EU legislation that is currently being drafted by Brussels. The letter comes as the EC's Competition Directorate General has ratcheted up the pressure on big gas utilities, launching two anti-trust actions using existing powers, indirectly strengthening Brussels' stand in any behind-the-scenes negotiations over the law. One case alleges market sharing by E.ON and Gaz de France, with the utilities supposedly agreeing to keep out of each other's home market after the 2004 liberalization of the European gas markets. Meanwhile, the EC is drafting new Euro VI vehicle emission standards for heavy lorries, buses, and coaches, which are being developed separately from the planned Euro VI standards for cars. Brussels is considering four design rules capping NOx, hydrocarbons, and particulate matter that either mirror US standards or are tougher. Brussels will also support the proposed 4300-km Trans-Saharan gas pipeline linking Nigeria with either Beni Saf or El Kala in Algeria. The pipeline's capacity would be 30 billion cu m/yr.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; Connecticut; establishment of interim progress for the annual fine particle national ambient air quality standard
Abstract: EPA approves a SIP revision submitted by the State of Connecticut. This revision establishes early fine particulate (PM2.5) transportation conformity emission budgets for the Connecticut portion of the New York-Northern New Jersey-Long Island, NYNJ-CT PM2.5 nonattainment area. This action is being taken under the Clean Air Act. The PM2.5 attainment demonstration must include motor vehicle emissions budgets for direct PM2.5 (including re-entrained road dust and/or highway and transit construction dust if determined significant contributors), and any PM2.5 precursors determined to be significant (which may include NOx, VOC, SO2, and NH3). The SIP must clearly identify the budgets (motor vehicle emissions budgets) for transportation conformity purposes. This direct final rule will be effective on 10/29/2007, unless EPA receives adverse comments by 10/1/2007.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Revisions to the California state implementation plan, South Coast Air Quality Management District
Abstract: EPA is taking direct final action to approve revisions to the South Coast Air Quality Management District portion of the California SIP, which concern VOC emissions from refinery flares and storage tanks at petroleum facilities. The agency is approving local rules that regulate these emission sources under the CAAA. This rule is effective on 10/29/2007 without further notice, unless EPA receives adverse comments by 9/27/2007. If EPA receives such comments, it will publish a timely withdrawal in the Federal Register to notify the public that this direct final rule will not take effect.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: General Interest - Quick takes: Industry seeks more time to meet fuel rules
Abstract: On 8/13/2007, the Western States Petroleum Association (WSPA) petitioned the CARB for a more reasonable timeframe for meeting new fuel rules approved by the board. CARB has 30 days to respond. CARB, on 6/14/2007, amended California's reformulated gasoline rules to allow increased use of ethanol and lower-carbon fuels. The new rule gives refiners 2 yr to comply or face punitive and costly penalties.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Aprroval and promulgation of implementation plans; New Jersey; Low emission vehicle program
Abstract: EPA is approving a SIP revision submitted by the State of New Jersey. The State's revision adopts California's second generation low emission vehicle program for light-duty vehicles, LEV II, beginning with the 2009 model year. EPA is not taking action on two provisions of New Jersey's program: the zero-emission vehicle sales mandate and the greenhouse gas emission standards. The New Jersey LEV program was adopted on 11/28/2005, published in the New Jersey State Register on 1/17/2006, is codified in Title 7, Chapter 27, Subchapter 29 of the New Jersey Administrative Code and replaces Subchapter 26, "Ozone Transport Commission?Low Emission Vehicles Program", which is now being removed from the SIP. The intended effect of this rulemaking is to approve a control strategy which will result in emissions reductions that will help New Jersey achieve attainment of national ambient air quality standard for ozone. This rule will be effective on 9/26/2007.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; State of Colorado; Revised Denver and Longmont carbon monoxide maintenance plans, and approval of related revisions
Abstract: In this direct final action, EPA is approving a SIP revision submitted by the State of Colorado on 9/25/2006. These revised maintenance plans address maintenance of the CO standard for a second 10-yr period beyond redesignation, extends the horizon years, and contains revised transportation conformity budgets for CO for the years 2013 and 2021 for Denver, and 2010, 2015, and 2020 for Longmont. In addition, Regulation No. 11, "Motor Vehicle Emissions Inspection Program", and Regulation No. 13, "Oxygenated Fuels Program", are removed from Denver's and Longmont's revised CO maintenance plans. EPA is approving Denver's and Longmont's revised CO maintenance plans, and the revised transportation conformity budgets. EPA is also approving the removal of Regulation No. 11 and Regulation No. 13 from Denver's and Longmont's revised CO maintenance plans. This action is being taken under section 110 of the Clean Air Act. This direct final rule is effective on 10/16/2007 without further notice, unless EPA receives adverse comment by 9/17/2007.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plans; Louisiana; Clean air interstate rule nitrogen oxides trading programs
Abstract: EPA is proposing to approve a revision to the Louisiana SIP submitted by the State of Louisiana on 7/12/2007, as the Louisiana Clean Air Interstate Rule (CAIR) NOx Trading Programs abbreviated SIP. The abbreviated SIP revision includes the Louisiana methodology for allocation of annual and ozone season NOx allowances. EPA is proposing to determine that the Louisiana CAIR NOx Trading Programs abbreviated SIP revision satisfies the applicable requirements of a CAIR abbreviated SIP revision. This action is aimed to reduce NOx emissions from the State of Louisiana that are contributing to nonattainment of the 8-hr ozone and PM2.5 NAAQS in downwind states. Comments must be received on or before 9/14/2007.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of Saint Regis Mohawk's tribal implementation plan
Abstract: EPA) is proposing to approve portions of the proposed St. Regis Mohawk Tribe's (SRMT) tribal implementation plan (TIP) to improve air quality within the exterior boundaries of the St. Regis Mohawk Reservation that are in accordance with federal requirements. EPA previously approved the SRMT for treatment-in-the-same-manner-as-a-state under the Clean Air Act for purposes of administering a TIP on 3/3/2003. The proposed TIP establishes Tribal ambient air quality standards for SO2, particulate matter, NO2, O3, fluoride, and heavy metals; includes an emissions inventory; provides regulations for permitting, source surveillance, open burning and enforcement; and defines SRMT's program for review of state permits and regional haze planning. This action will make federally enforceable the approvable portions of the SRMT?s proposed TIP. Comments must be received on or before 9/13/2007.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Revisions to the Arizona state implementation plan, Maricopa County
Abstract: EPA is taking direct final action to approve a revision to the Maricopa County portion of the Arizona SIP. This revision concerns reductions of particulate matter (PM) emissions from the paving of unpaved roads and the use of these reductions to satisfy the offset requirements under the new source review provisions of the CAAA. EPA is approving a local rule, which assures that the PM emission reductions resulting from the road paving meet the criteria for valid offsets under the CAAA. This rule is effective on 10/5/2007 without further notice, unless EPA receives adverse comments by 9/5/2007.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plans; Iowa; Clean air interstate rule
Abstract: EPA is taking final action to approve a revision to the Iowa SIP submitted on 8/15/2006. This revision addresses the requirements of EPA's Clean Air Interstate Rule (CAIR) promulgated on 5/12/2005, and subsequently revised on 4/28/2006, and 12/13/2006. EPA has determined that the SIP revision fully implements the CAIR requirements for Iowa. As a result of this action, EPA will also withdraw, through a separate rulemaking, the CAIR Federal Implementation Plans concerning SO2, NOx annual, and NOx ozone season emissions for Iowa. CAIR requires States to reduce emissions of SO2 and NOx that significantly contribute to, and interfere with maintenance of, the NAAQS for fine particulates and/or ozone in any downwind state. This rule is effective on 9/5/2007.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval of implementation plans of Georgia: Clean air interstate rule
Abstract: EPA is proposing to approve a revision to the Georgia SIP submitted on 3/28/2007. This revision addresses the requirements of EPA's Clean Air Interstate Rule (CAIR), promulgated on 5/12/2005, and subsequently revised on 4/28/2006, and 12/13/2006. EPA is proposing to determine that the SIP revision fully implements the CAIR requirements for Georgia. Thus, as a consequence of the SIP approval, EPA will also withdraw the CAIR Federal Implementation Plans (CAIR FIP) concerning SO2 and NOx annual emissions for Georgia. The CAIR FIP for all States in the CAIR region were promulgated on 4/28/2006, and subsequently revised on 12/13/2006. CAIR requires States to reduce emissions of SO2 and NOx that significantly contribute to nonattainment of, and interfere with maintenance of, the NAAQS for fine particulates and/or ozone in any downwind state. Under the NOx allowance allocation methodology in the CAIR model trading rules and in the CAIR FIP, NOx annual and ozone season allowances are allocated to units that have operated for 5 yr, based on heat input data from a 3-yr period that are adjusted for fuel type by using fuel factors of 1 for coal, 0.6 for oil, and 0.4 for other fuels. Comments must be received on or before 9/4/2007.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval of implementation plans of Florida: Clean air interstate rule
Abstract: EPA is proposing to approve a revision to the Florida SIP submitted on 3/16/2007. This revision addresses the requirements of EPA's Clean Air Interstate Rule (CAIR), promulgated on 5/12/2005, and subsequently revised on 4/28/2006, and 12/13/2006. EPA is proposing to determine that the SIP revision fully implements the CAIR requirements for Florida. Thus, as a consequence of the SIP approval, EPA will also withdraw the CAIR Federal Implementation Plans (CAIR FIP) concerning SO2, NOx annual, and NOx ozone season emissions for Florida. The CAIR FIP for all States in the CAIR region were promulgated on 4/28/2006, and subsequently revised on 12/13/2006. CAIR requires States to reduce emissions of SO2 and NOx that significantly contribute to nonattainment of, and interfere with maintenance of, the NAAQS for fine particulates and/or ozone in any downwind state. Under the NOx allowance allocation methodology in the CAIR model trading rules and in the CAIR FIP, NOx annual and ozone season allowances are allocated to units that have operated for 5 yr, based on heat input data from a 3-yr period that are adjusted for fuel type by using fuel factors of 1 for coal, 0.6 for oil, and 0.4 for other fuels. Comments must be received on or before 9/4/2007.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Processes for reducing NHS carbon footprint.
Abstract: NHS Trust boards face challenging targets for cutting carbon emissions from new and existing facilities. Spirax Sarco's Murdo Macdonald looks at the help available and some of the latest examples of good practice in steam systems for hospital heating and hot water.
Index Keywords: carbon dioxide; air pollution; article; hospital service; national health service; practice guideline; public hospital; United Kingdom; Air Pollution; Carbon Dioxide; Great Britain; Guidelines; Hospitals, Public; Maintenance and Engineering, Hospital; State Medicine

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Natural gas trucks haul into ports
Abstract: San Pedro Bay ports are replacing diesel with alternative fuels to reduce emissions at the two largest US container seaports. The twin San Pedro Bay facilities, the Port of Los Angeles (POLA), and the Port of Long Beach (POLB) handle 40% of the nations containerized cargo. The San Pedro Bay Ports Clean Air Action Plan was approved in November 2006 with a goal to cut diesel particulate matter (PM) emissions by over 50% and NO emissions by more than 45% within the next five years. The major parts of the plan focus on reducing emissions from ships, harbor craft, cargo handling equipment, and locomotives. The Clean Air Action Plan includes replacing approximately 5300 diesel trucks with liquefied natural gas (LNG) trucks by the year 2011. The California South Coast Air Quality Management District (SCAQMD) has approved the acquisition and deployment of 20 new Kenworth T800 trucks fitted with Westport Innovation Inc.'s LNG system for heavy-duty trucks.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Opinion divided over Brown's green towns
Abstract: New British Prime Minister Gordon Brown has stated plans to build 100,000 carbon-neutral homes in five eco-towns. For Paul Harvey, the former leader of Basingstoke & Deane District Council and serving Labor councilor, he thinks that the plan is serious enough and thinks that it will not fall victim to whatever happened to similar initiatives. Brown is simply recognizing the need for younger people to purchase affordable homes, at a lesser carbon footprint. For Jon Whitehouse, leader of the Liberal Democrat Group at Epping Forest District Council, he takes on a neutral stand, but calls for stricter standard. For Frank Browne, leader of Wokingham District Council, the initiative will just fall victim to other similar plans that were easier said than done. He says that Brown and his colleagues are not aware of the cost associated with the development. In addition, while the homes are 25% more costly than standard homes and yet must at all cost be affordable, it will be difficult for developers to sustain such an extremely tight margin.
Index Keywords: affordable housing; ecological footprint; environmental planning; standard (regulation); sustainability; urban development; urban planning; Eurasia; Europe; United Kingdom; Western Europe

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: News: Government: EU emissions target 'unrealistic'
Abstract: The proposed EU CO2 emissions target for automobiles of 130 g/km by 2012 was damned as "unrealistic" at a Fédération Internationale de l'Automobile (FIA) conference of manufacturers, legislators, and transport interests. According to Dr. Reinhardt Kolke, the consumption of CNG, LPG, and ethanol represent < 1% in every vehicle class and will not be much more significant by 2012. The biggest market shift will come in diesel use during the next 6 yr or so, for example, the diesel market share for a family car, currently at 70%, will increase to 75% by 2012. For a small family car, the equivalent figures are 58 and 62%, thus a focus on diesel formulation and car propulsion would be more effective. In the US, a further 10 states have followed California in developing fuel economy standards that will cover some 35% of the country's total population. The FIA favors a progressive, upward convergence of car fuel efficiency standards at a global level and backs the development of a global fuel economy standard via the UN Economic Commission for Europe's World Forum for Harmonisation of Vehicle Regulations. Such a standard could become a norm for fuel economy and CO2 emissions reduction.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Revisions to the Arizona state implementation plan, Pinal County air quality control district
Abstract: EPA is finalizing a limited approval and limited disapproval of revisions to the Pinal County Air Quality Control District portion of the Arizona SIP. EPA proposed a limited approval because these rules improve the SIP and are largely consistent with the relevant CAA requirements. Simultaneously, EPA proposed a limited disapproval because some rule provisions conflict with section 110 and part D of the Act. These provisions include the Rule 8071 (Unpaved Vehicle/Equipment Traffic Areas). This action was proposed in the Federal Register on 10/7/2006 and concerns particulate matter emissions from fugitive dust. Under authority of the CAAA, this action simultaneously approves local rules that regulate these emission sources and directs Arizona to correct rule deficiencies. This rule is effective on 8/31/2007.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plans; Implementation plan revision; State of New Jersey
Abstract: EPA is approving a request from the State of New Jersey to revise its SIP for ozone to incorporate state-adopted amendments to Subchapter 19 "Control and Prohibition of Air Pollution from Oxides of Nitrogen" and related amendments to Subchapter 16 "Control and Prohibition of Air Pollution by Volatile Organic Compounds." The amendments relate to the control of NOx emissions from stationary industrial sources. This SIP revision consists of control measures needed to meet the shortfall in emission reductions in New Jersey's 1-hr ozone attainment demonstration SIP as identified by EPA. The intended effect of this action is to approve the state control strategy, which will lead to emission reductions that will help realize attainment of the NAAQS for ozone required by the Clean Air Act. This rule will be effective on 8/30/2007.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Partial withdrawal of direct final rule revising the California State Implementation Plan, San Joaquin Valley Air Pollution Control District
Abstract: On 5/30/2007 (72 FR 29886), EPA published a direct final approval of revisions to the California SIP. These revisions concerned San Joaquin Valley Air Pollution Control District (SJVAPCD) Rule 4307, Boilers, Steam Generators and Process Heaters-2.0 million (MM)Btu/hr to 5.0 MMBtu/hr; Rule 4308, Boilers, Steam Generators and Process Heaters-0.075 MMBtu/hr to 2.0 MMBtu/hr; Rule 4309, Dryers, Dehydrators, and Ovens; Rule 4352, Solid Fuel Fired Boilers, Steam Generators and Process Heaters; and Rule 4905, Natural Gas-Fired, Fan-Type Residential Central Furnaces. The direct final action was published without prior proposal because EPA anticipated no adverse comment. The direct final rule stated that if adverse comments were received by 6/29/2007, EPA would publish a timely withdrawal in the Federal Register. EPA received timely adverse comments. Consequently, with this revision, it is withdrawing the direct final approval of SJVAPCD Rule 4352. EPA will either address the comments in a subsequent final action based on the parallel proposal also published on 5/30/2007 (72 FR 29901), or repropose an alternative action. The agency will not institute a second comment period on a subsequent final action. The other rules approved in the 5/30/2007 direct final action, SJVAPCD Rules 4307, 4308, 4309, and 4905, are not affected by this partial withdrawal and are incorporated into the SIP as of the effective date of the 5/30/2007 direct final action. This rule and withdrawal are effective on 7/30/2007.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plans; Texas; Clean Air Interstate Rule Nitrogen Oxides Annual Trading Program
Abstract: EPA is taking a direct final action to approve a revision to the Texas SIP submitted by the State of Texas on 8/4/2006, as the Texas Clean Air Interstate Rule (CAIR) NOx Annual Abbreviated SIP. The abbreviated SIP revision EPA is approving includes the Texas methodologies for allocation of annual NOx allowances for Phase 1 of CAIR, the control periods 2009-2014, and for allocating allowances from the compliance supplement pool (CSP) in the CAIR NOx annual trading program. Upon the effective date of approval of the Texas CAIR NOx Annual Abbreviated SIP revision, EPA by ministerial action will note in the Texas CAIR NOx Annual Federal Implementation Plan's (FIP) incorporated regulations that the Texas rules for annual NOx allowances under Phase 1 of CAIR and allocating allowances from the CSP apply, rather than the Federal FIP rules. The intended effect of this action is to reduce NOx emissions from the State of Texas that are contributing to nonattainment of the PM2.5 NAAQS in downwind states. This action is being taken under section 110 of the Federal Clean Air Act. This rule is effective on 9/28/2007 without further notice, unless EPA receives relevant adverse comment by 8/29/2007.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plans Tennessee; Approval of revisions to the Tennessee SIP and the Nashville/Davidson County portion of the Tennessee SIP; Prevention of significant deterioration and nonattainment new source review
Abstract: EPA is proposing to approve SIP revisions submitted by the State of Tennessee on 2/23/2006 and 5/31/2006. The proposed revisions modify Tennessee's and Nashville/Davidson County's Prevention of Significant Deterioration and Nonattainment New Source Review (NNSR) regulations in the SIP to address changes to the federal NSR regulations, which were promulgated by EPA on 12/31/2002 (67 FR 80186) and reconsidered with minor changes on 117/2003 (68 FR 63021) (these two final actions are collective called the 2002 NSR Reform Rules). EPA's 2002 NSR Reform Rules, proposed for inclusion in the Tennessee SIP and the Nashville/Davidson County portion of the Tennessee SIP, contain provisions for baseline emissions calculations, an actual-to-projected actual methodology for calculating emissions changes, options for plant-wide applicability limits, and recordkeeping and reporting requirements. Comments must be received on or before 8/22/2007. List of Subjects in 40 CFR Part 52 include environmental protection, air pollution control, CO, intergovernmental relations, lead, nitrogen dioxide, ozone, particulate matter, reporting and recordkeeping requirements, SOx, and VOC.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plans; Louisiana; clean air interstate rule sulfur dioxide trading program
Abstract: EPA is taking a direct final action to approve a revision to the Louisiana SIP submitted on 9/22/2006, enacted at Louisiana Administrative Code, Title 33, Part III, Chapter 5, Section 506(C) (LAC 33:III.506(C)). This revision addresses the requirements of EPA's Clean Air Interstate Rule (CAIR) Sulfur Dioxide Trading Program, promulgated on 5/12/2005 and subsequently revised on 4/28/2006. EPA is approving the SIP revision as fully implementing the CAIR SO2 requirements for Louisiana. EPA will also withdraw the CAIR Federal Implementation Plan concerning SO2 emissions for the state. CAIR requires States to reduce emissions of SO2 and NOx that significantly contribute to, and interfere with maintenance of, the NAAQS for fine particulates and/or ozone in any downwind state. The intended effect of this action is to reduce SO2 emissions from Louisiana that are contributing to nonattainment of the PM2.5 NAAQS in downwind states. This action is being taken under section 110 of the Federal Clean Air Act. This rule is effective on 9/18/2007 without further notice, unless EPA receives relevant adverse comment by 8/20/2007.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plans; New York emission statement program
Abstract: EPA is proposing to approve the SIP revision submitted by the State of New York on 7/7/2006 for the purpose of enhancing an existing Emission Statement Program for stationary sources in New York. The SIP revision consists of amendments to Title 6 of the New York Codes Rules and Regulations, Chapter III, Part 202, Subpart 202-2, Emission Statements. The SIP revision was submitted by New York to satisfy the ozone nonattainment provisions of the Clean Air Act. These provisions require states in which all or part of any ozone nonattainment area is located to submit a revision to its SIP which requires owner/operators of stationary sources of VOC and NOx to provide the State with a statement, at least annually, of the source's actual emissions of VOC and NOx. The Emission Statement SIP revision EPA proposes to approve enhances the reporting requirements for VOC and NOx and expands the reporting requirement, based on specified emission thresholds, to include CO, SO2, PM2.5, PM10, NH3, Pb, and Pb compounds and hazardous air pollutants. The intended effect is to obtain improved emissions related data from facilities located in New York, allowing New York to more effectively plan for and attain the NAAQS. The Emission Statement rule also improves EPA's and the public's access to facility-specific emission related data. Comments must be received on or before 8/20/2007.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; Minnesota
Abstract: EPA is taking final action to approve revisions to the Minnesota SIP for SO2 submitted on 4/23/2007. Specifically, the revisions involve Continental Nitrogen & Resource Corp of Dakota County, MN. The emission limits for the Continental Nitrogen steam boilers using No. 6 fuel oil are removed. Continental Nitrogen has physically disconnected its three boilers. The boilers cannot operate, thus there are no emissions. This direct final rule will be effective on 9/17/2007, unless EPA receives adverse comments by 8/20/2007.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation; North Dakota; revisions to new source review rules
Abstract: EPA is taking final action to approve North Dakota's revisions to their Air Pollution Control Rules Chapter 33-15-15 (Prevention of Significant Deterioration of Air Quality), submitted by North Dakota on 2/10/2005,that relate to the State's Prevention of Significant Deterioration (PSD) construction permit program. These revisions to Chapter 33-15-15 were adopted by the North Dakota Department of Health on 2/1/2005, and supersede and replace the previous SIP-approved Chapter 33-15-15 PSD Regulations. This action is being taken under section 110 of the Clean Air Act. North Dakota is in attainment for all pollutants (CO, NO2, particulate matter, O3, SOx, and VOC) and does not have a SIP-approved non-attainment permit program. This final rule is effective on 8/20/2007.

Authors: Committee to Review the U.S. Climate Change Science Program's Synthesis and Assessment Product 3.3, Board on Atmospheric Sciences and Climate, Division on Earth and Life Studies, National Research Council
Title: Review of the U.S. Climate Change Science Program's Synthesis and Assessment Product 3.3, "Weather and Climate Extremes in a Changing Climate"
Source title: Review of the U.S. Climate Change Science Program's Synthesis and Assessment Product 3.3, "Weather and Climate Extremes in a Changing Climate"
Authors with affiliations: Committee to Review the U.S. Climate Change Science Program's Synthesis and Assessment Product 3.3; Board on Atmospheric Sciences and Climate; Division on Earth and Life Studies; National Research Council
Abstract: The committee reviewed draft Synthesis and Assessment Product 3.3, Weather and Climate Extremes in a Changing Climate, focusing on the extent to which the document meets the requirements set forth in its prospectus and using guidelines developed by the U.S. Climate Change Science Program in conjunction with the National Research Council. The committee finds that the draft provides a good and thorough assessment of the important issues regarding extreme events over North America and how they may change in the context of a changing climate. The document may be improved by considering several recommendations regarding its content and format outlined later in this review. © 2007 by the National Academy of Sciences. All rights reserved.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Environment: United States: Cars to get cleaner
Abstract: A new report from UBS, a bank, and Ricardo, a motoring consultancy, will be good news for makers of diesel and hybrid cars in the US. The report predicts demand for both kinds of engines will boom, with diesel sales of 1.5 million/yr and hybrid sales of 1.2 million by 2012. Diesel will remain slightly more popular because it is cheaper. The carmakers share the enthusiasm with Mercedes, VW, BMW, Nissan, and Honda recently announcing new plans for clean diesel in the US. The basis for the growth is US President Bush's declaration in mid-May that his government departments must prepare new regulations by the end of 2008 aimed at cutting petroleum use and greenhouse-gas emissions. Diesel and hybrid-engine vehicle manufacturers will both benefit from these changes but the former will remain cheaper and more popular. Its problem will be to meet tough regulations on NOx emissions, which are stricter than similar legislation in the European Union.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Secretary of State opens UPM renewable energy plant
Abstract: The Rt. Hon. Peter Hain, the Secretary of State for Wales, has opened a £52 million renewable energy plant at UPM Shotton in North Wales. The project has been described crucial in tackling carbon emissions and minimizing environmental impact. The new plant is being used to combust all residue produced from the paper mill's recovered paper recycling process using biomass fuels. The investment has also enhanced the mill's self sufficiency in in heat by up to 95% and in power by up to 25%. UPM's carbon dioxide emissions will be reduced by 30,000 tonnes annually. The new plant is part of an investment series being undertaken by the parent company, UPM-Kymmene, which also announced an investment of £59 million in a renewable energy plant for its Caledonian paper mill in Ayrshire, Scotland.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Projects: Quoddy Bay LNG facility to use new vaporization technology
Abstract: Quoddy Bay LNG announced a new development will be incorporated into its 2 bcf/day LNG import facility to be located in Washington County, ME. Black & Veatch has developed a new patent-pending vaporization technology for the facility that will reduce the pollution causing air emissions by ≈ 75%. The new technology will reduce emissions at the facility, including CO and NOx using fired heater with ultra low NOx burners in conjunction with condensing waste heat recovery units to reheat the super-cooled LNG back to a gas so that it can be sent into pipelines. This technology could conceivably allow one large facility like Quoddy Bay's to be built in the place of three to four smaller ones and yet have the air emissions impact of only one. Operations will be in early 2010.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Hi-speed technology: MTU workboat engines meet new emissions standards
Abstract: The MTU Series 4000 high speed workboat diesel engines comply with the EPA Tier II and CCNR (ZKR) Stage 2 regulations, which fix maximum NOx and HC emissions at 7.2 g/kw-hr, maximum CO emissions at 5 g/kw-hr and maximum particulate emissions at 0.2 g/kw-hr. The low emission characteristics mean that MTU engines meet the requirements of the promotional program for lower emission inland waterway diesel engines run by the German Federal Ministry of Transport, Building and Urban Affairs. Available in 8V, 12V and 16V versions, the series covers a performance range from 700 to 2000 kw.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Surveyor 1 & 2
Abstract: Made shipyard, the Netherlands, has delivered two hydrographic survey vessels, known as Surveyor 1 and 2, to the Rotterdam Port Authority for carrying out fast and eco-friendly waterway surveying. The two vessels are built according to the rules of the Dutch Shipping Inspectorate for Inland Waterways and the ADNR (Regulation for the Carriage of Dangerous Substances on the Rhine (EU) 7.1.2.19.1 regulations. The Surveyors are loaded with state-of-the-art technology that provides extremely quite and ergonomic operations. The vessels are capable of gathering data regarding the depth of the waterways, the state of the bottom, the salinity level, the currents, the pollution, and the thickness of the mud layer on the bottom. The vessels are also well oversized with 2×50 kW, while all engine exhausts are equipped with sooth filters and catalytic units, reducing emission of particles by 95%, and reducing carbon monoxide (CO) and hydrocarbon (HC) emissions by 80%.
Index Keywords: Machine design; Particulate emissions; Shipbuilding; Shipyards; hydrographic survey; ship design; shipbuilding; vessel; Benelux; Eurasia; Europe; Netherlands; Western Europe

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Burning subsurface deposits
Abstract: Putzmeister and Boss Pro-Tech jointly developed and supplied a mobile mixing and pumping system, to be used for extinguishing subsurface fires in open coal pits in the Kosovan brown coal district. The new system was implemented to save subsurface coal deposits and reduce the release of carbon dioxide 2 (CO2) and other toxic gases from the open pits. The combined mixing and pumping system consists of componenents, such as a material collection containe, with trough chain conveyor as temporary silo, a mobile screw conveyor, a container platform, and an office container. The companies paid significant attention to providing each of these components, with the best mobility and transportability, during the design process of the new system. The new mixing and pumping system has also been designed for a capacity of 17 m 3 per hour.
Index Keywords: Carbon dioxide; Coal; Conveyors; Mine fires; Coal pits; Mobile mixing and pumping system; Trough chain conveyor; Product development

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Tracking the carbon
Abstract: The Australian plantations industry will work with researchers and governments to develop standards that ensure carbon in timber. The Australian state and federal governments have released their views on a possible emissions trading scheme, resulting in less uncertainty about Australia's policy response to climate change. The Australian Prime Minister's Task Group on Emissions Trading has proposed broader coverage of emissions to all major emitters plus transport compared with National Emissions Trading Taskforce's (NETT) stationary energy. A working group has been formed to focus on developing a national market for trading forestry carbon offsets, which will work on an industry-based forest carbon certification scheme that ensures forest and wood products-based carbon credits are from sustainably managed forests and plantations.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Landfill yields LNG for vehicle fuel
Abstract: The world's first plant to produce LNG from landfill gas is now being commissioned in Irvine, CA, by Prometheus Energy Co. The first module is expected to reach its capacity of around 5000 gal/day by fall. Other modules will be added later to use the landfill's capacity of 50,000 gal/day. The plant produces LNG of 97%+ methane concentration for transportation fuel, the first customer being the local Orange County Transit Authority. The advantages are that it uses an otherwise wasted biogas, and it reduces gas-transportation costs, since the nearest fuel-grade LNG plants are in Arizona, Wyoming, and Texas. The landfill gas contains about 50% methane, 40% CO2, and 10% nitrogen. Minor contaminants, including sulfur compounds, are removed by conventional means, then most of the CO2 is removed by freezing and pressure-swing adsorption. Finally, the CO2 content is reduced to about 50 ppm by temperature-swing adsorption.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Alternative fuel sources
Abstract: Alternatives to petroleum fuels such as biodiesel and ethanol, which are domestically produced, and environmentally friendly can help to decrease dependency on foreign oils and reduce greenhouse gas emissions, allowing companies to make a better working environment for employees.
