Biodiesel can be used in most existing engines with few or new modifications to the engine or fuel system. Biodiesel, which can be manufactured within the US with surplus vegetable oils, using existing industrial production capacity and conventional equipment, can help to increase energy security in the US. Ethanol is also a domestically produced renewable fuel source made from feedstock. It also reduces the amount of greenhouse gas emission significantly, and is proving to be more cost effective to the consumers. Researchers are looking to find the right blend of ethanol, diesel, and other fuel additives to replace diesel in the engines of heavy polluters, including off-road equipment and city buses.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Advancing hydraulic hybrids
Abstract: Bosch Rexroth will supply its Hydrostatic Regenerative Brake (HRB) parallel hydraulic hybrid technology into prototype refuse vehicles for field testing and evaluation in two metro areas. The system will be installed into a prototype refuse chassis, and the project is sponsored by the New York State Energy and Research Development Authority (NYSERDA) and the National Association of State Energy Officials (NASEO). The US Department of Energy will promote multistate initiatives in new energy technology to assist widespread application of hydraulic hybrid powertrains in vehicle fleets, such as refuse haulers, that have been identified as having high potential for successfully using this technology to reduce fuel consumption and emissions. The specific objective of the field tests is to validate the technical and economic characteristics of the HRB system, a key step in defining a program for deploying this product to large numbers of in-service and new vehicles.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Cash available for clean diesel projects... hydrogen buses for Orlando... CWI engines for China buses
Abstract: The US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) is making a fund of $1.7 million available for clean diesel projects under the 2007 Northeast Diesel Collaborative Emissions Reductions Grant Program. Clean School Bus USA and the Voluntary Diesel Retrofit program are the two national clean diesel programs under which the project applications are being accepted. All the projects are required to benefit the air quality in the geographic areas. Puerto Rico has unveiled its first school bus retrofitted with emissions control technology to reduce toxic diesel emissions and improve air quality for local school children. The South Coast Air Quality Management District (SCAQMD) has approved $2.9 million for the immediate acquisition and deployment of 20 Westport liquefied natural gas (LNG) heavy- duty trucks at the Port of Los Angeles (POLA) and Port of Long Beach (POLB). The EPA has released two new documents examining the cost-effectiveness of Heavy-Duty Diesel Retrofits and Other Mobile Source Emission Reduction Projects and Programs.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Around the industry
Abstract: Some of the recent business scenario of the power industry market are discussed. AFC Energy plc of Las Vegas, Nevada, has entered into a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with the state Ministry for Development of Disadvantaged Areas of the Republic of Indonesia. The MOU relates to the Community Integrated Utility Program project that aims to provide 32 million households with the ability to produce electricity and potable drinking water. POSCO Power, distribution partner of FuelCell Energy Inc. of Danbury, Connecticut, has sold 5.1MW of Direct FuelCell™ (DFC) power plants that will allow electric utility customers in South Korea to generate clean energy and comply with greenhouse gas reduction targets. Each of three projects will operate in a grid-support capacity, supplying energy directly onto the existing electric network. Millennium Cell Inc. in Eatontown, New Jersey has received additional funding from the National Center for Manufacturing Sciences (NCMS).
Index Keywords: Electric utilities; Greenhouse gases; Potable water; Power plants; Project management; Clean energy; Memorandum of understanding (MOU); Power industry; Industrial management

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: News: Downstream: Clean coal project planned in Australia
Abstract: BP and Rio Tinto are beginning feasibility studies and work on plans for the potential development of a $1.5 billion coal-fired power generation project in Western Australia. This will be the first new project for Hydrogen Energy, the new company recently launched by BP and Rio Tinto, subject to regulatory approval. The project would be fully integrated with carbon capture and storage to reduce its emissions of greenhouse gases. The project's gasification facility and power station would be located in Kwinana, alongside BP's refinery and Rio Tinto's Hlsmelt facility, gasifying locally-produced coal from the Collie region to produce hydrogen and CO2. The power plant, which would be fueled by H2, would be capable of producing 500 Mw of low-carbon electricity. Subject to the successful outcome of detailed engineering and commercial studies, and providing government policy is in place to make the project commercially viable, a final investment decision to develop the project could be made in 2011, with the project coming into operation after a 3-yr construction period.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: The rose of Suriname
Abstract: IAMGOLD's recently-acquired Rosebel mine, located in the Brokopondo district of Suriname, northeast South America, has expanded its reserves and is presently evaluating its second major expansion since start-up in 2004. Last year, continuing development drilling of the existing deposits continued as well as exploration for new deposits on the Rosebel property. Additional exploration was carried out on the adjacent Headley's Reef and Thunder Mountain exploration permits, as well on the Sara Creek project. Loading and hauling are controlled through a truck dispatch system. The mining equipment is entirely owned by IAMGOLD and operated by IAMGOLD employees. Equipments include a Caterpillar 5130B and 5130, Caterpillar 992C, Caterpillar 777B and 777D models. The Rosebel process consists of a crushing and grinding circuit followed by a conventional gravity circuit, cyanidation circuit and carbon-in-leach plant. The other project, referred to as the Rosebel Phase 2 construction, was completed at a final cost of US$16.5 million. The crushed ore from the gyratory is stockpiled using the stacker/ reclaimer system. All of the water used at the processing plant is now recycled, so there is no need to take water from the environment.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: China: Another gas pipeline to fuel the East
Abstract: China has launched a new gas pipeline to run from SW Sichuan to coastal Shanghai to fuel the East, following its ambitious West-East gas project. The new 1700-km pipeline is expected to transport 12 billion cu m/yr from the Puguang field in Sichuan Province to the central and eastern regions that include Hubei, Anhui, Jiangxi, Jiangsu, Zhejiang provinces, and Shanghai. The project will serve as another "energy artery" for the country in addition to the West-East gas pipeline, which runs > 4000 km from NW Xinjiang to Shanghai and began operation in 2004. If it proceeds on time, the $8.25 project will start operation at the beginning of 2010. When it is completed, the clean energy resource is expected to help reduce CO2 emission by tens of millions of tons annually. Proven reserves of the Puguang gasfield may reach 430 billion cu m by the end of 2007.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Newsreel: Consumers want energy independence but still prefer NIMBY
Abstract: According to an annual survey by RBC Capital Markets, while 90% said the US needs to find ways to produce more of its own oil rather than rely so heavily on foreign sources and 80% said they were concerned about energy self-sufficiency, most Americans oppose the construction of oil refineries or other traditional energy plants in their city or town. The survey found 84% opposed construction of an oil refinery in their hometown, 83% opposed construction or re-commissioning of a nuclear power plant, and 75% opposed construction of a LNG facility in their city or town. Compared to a year ago, Americans are far more concerned about global warming and climate change, and are increasingly conscious of the harm CO2 emissions are causing. Most favor CO2 regulations, even if it meant higher energy costs, and would also rather pay more for cleaner fuels than pay less for fuels that pollute.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: China: Cross-province coalbed-methane pipeline planned
Abstract: China is planning to build its first cross-province coalbed methane (CBM) pipeline within the next 12 mo, and is awaiting approval from the National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC). The pipeline will run from Duanshi County in Shanxi Province and end in Bo'ai County, in Henan Province, passing through Qinshui basin in Shanxi. The 120-km long Duanshi-Bo'ai line will have a capacity of 1 billion cu m/yr, and the total investment in the project will be $53-$66.5 million. The pipeline will also ease the gas supply shortage in Henan Province. The province has a natural gas shortage of 1 billion cu m/yr. China is expected to construct 10 CBM pipelines by the end of 2010, according to the 11th Five-Year Plan (2006-10) for the CBM industry. The pipelines will have a total length of 1441 km and capacity of 6.53 billion cu m/yr.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: News in brief: North America: United States: Sinclair Tulsa Refining is planning...
Abstract: Sinclair Tulsa Refining is planning a $1 billion project at its refinery in Tulsa, OK, to reduce emissions and increase its crude-processing capacity from 70,000 to 115,000 bpd. The expansion is set for completion by late 2010.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: China: Chinese cross-province coalbed-methane pipeline planned
Abstract: China plans to build the country's first cross-province coalbed methane (CBM) pipeline within the next 12 mo, which will run from Duanshi County in North China's Shanxi Province and end in Bohai County, in Central China's Henan Province, passing through Qinshui basin in Shanxi. The 120-km long Duanshi-Bo'ai line will have a capacity of 1 billion cu m/yr and a total investment of $53-$66.5 million. China is expected to construct 10 CBM pipelines by the end of 2010, with a total length of 1441 km and capacity of 6.53 billion cu m/yr.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Analysis: Technip focused on oil and gas
Abstract: According to Thierry Pilenko, Technip's new CEO, the company will maintain its focus on the oil and gas business and seek to expand its technology base to boost profitability. Technip will focus on the development of subsea hydrocarbon fields, offshore platforms optimized for varying water depths, and major onshore projects, e.g., natural gas liquefaction, grass roots refineries, and new petrochemical units. The firm is also putting in place a new mentoring program in a bid to attract and retain talented new employees. The company will aim to develop offshore technologies for water depths of 3000 m and more; oil and gas exploration in Arctic regions; treatment of unconventional resources; onshore mega projects; and technologies to reduce CO2 emissions.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Analysis: Sasol's efforts to green CTL
Abstract: Sasol is planning to incorporate a new process consuming coal fines rather than coarse coal in the expansion of its coal-to-liquids (CTL) plant at Secunda, south Africa. The coal fines process will form part of a 30,000 bpd expansion of Sasol's Secunda, which will boost the complex capacity to 180,000 bpd. Coal fines will contribute 7500 bpd to the plant's output. The Secunda expansion will also include a 300 Mw cogeneration unit, which according to Sasol will reduce the amount of gas flared at Secunda while covering some of the plant's 1200 Mw power consumption, and a R4.5 billion program to decrease greenhouse gas emissions from Secunda by 10% from 2004 figures by 2015. As part of this program, Sasol has invested in N2O abatement at its two nitric acid plants based at Sasolburg and Secunda, using a secondary catalyst to convert N2O into nitrogen and oxygen. Meanwhile, Sasol is studying sites for a separate 80,000 bpd Greenfield CTL project, named "Project Mafutha". The plant is planned for an inland site, either in the Free State or Waterberg, and will help south Africa be more self-sufficient in transport fuels.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Business update: Plants and projects: ExxonMobil's advanced scrubbing technology selected by Valero
Abstract: Valero Energy has selected ExxonMobil Research and Engineering Co's Wet Gas Scrubbing Plus (EMRE WGS+) technology for its Memphis, TN, and Delaware City, DE, refineries. At the Memphis refinery, the technology was selected as part of an overall emissions reduction project on the 60,000 bpd FCC unit (FCCU). Hamon Research Cottrell is engineering and supplying an expanded wet gas scrubber, which significantly reduces sulfur and particulate emissions. As part of this project, HRC is also supplying EMRE WGS+ technology to significantly reduce NO emissions. At the Delaware City Refinery, the WGS+ technology is being engineered and supplied for a 60,000 bpd FCCU that has an existing scrubber used for the removal of sulfur and particulate matter. WGS+ technology is expected to significantly reduce NO emissions as well.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Chevron, FCE project uses restaurant grease
Abstract: Chevron Energy Solutions has begun engineering work on a system at the City of Rialtos wastewater treatment facility in California that will transform wastewater sludge and kitchen grease from local restaurants into clean, renewable power. The system includes FuelCell Energy's 900 kw fuel cell power plant that will generate electricity using methane produced naturally on-site by the organic materials in wastewater. Meanwhile, the fuel cell plant and other energy-efficient improvements will reduce greenhouse gas emissions by ∼ 5.5 million ton/yr.
